review_title: Whoop app‚Äôs potential to support mental health disorders
review_text:
As a student in Abnormal Psychology, I found the Whoop app to be equally interesting and relevant in how it relates to topics in my course. Especially concerning stress, anxiety, and sleep disorders. This app tracks physiological data like sleep cycles, heart rate variability, and recovery. Which are all relevant to the biological determinants of stress related conditions and anxiety disorders. Chronic stress for example, poor recovery scores or irregular heart rate patterns can show up due to heightened sympathetic nervous system activity. Heightened nervous system activity is often seen in individuals with PTSD and GAD. 
One of the most useful features of the Whoop app was the sleep coach. This feature aligns closely with disorders covered in class, it supports cognitive-behavioral approaches to insomnia, by encouraging good ‚Äúsleep hygiene‚Äù.  By tracking factors like strain or late-night activity and their impact on sleep quality. This could be helpful for individuals struggling with mood or anxiety disorders, where sleep is often disrupted. 
One thing I have noticed is that this constant monitoring could become counterproductive for some people. In abnormal Psych we have discussed how individuals with OCD or illness anxiety disorder can become hyper focused on their bodily sensations. In this context, an app like this may unintentionally trigger compulsive checking/tracking. While Whoop promotes healthy self-awareness it‚Äôs important to recognize the potential for mal use. 
Overall, I‚Äôve found that Whoop bridges the gap between technology and psychology, by offering health insight, and tracking how the body responds to stress and sleep. Whoop provides a great amount of biofeedback that supports wellbeing which could be used to support people struggling with stress, anxiety, and sleep disorders.

I‚Äôve never felt the need to write a poor review before but I‚Äôm shocked by the hidden 12 month commitment that comes with simply wanting to try the Whoop for a little longer past the free trial.

The Whoop is a great product, don‚Äôt get me wrong, it provides really granular analytics on my health and works how it‚Äôs advertised.

review_title: Tried it for a year; not for me
review_text:
Whoop appealed for me as a lower cost way to try out some smartwatch features. However, a caution to those considering the free trial: Some number of Whoop‚Äôs features will not calibrate in that first month. You would need to hang onto the device for longer to unlock insights or track your body temp over time.

The Whoop algorithms just don‚Äôt seem to work for me, an active middle-aged person who is not a self-described athlete. I had a lot of recovery and strain scores that did not match my energy level or perceived rate of exertion. The Whoop ‚ÄúInsights‚Äù tab just runs correlations, so don‚Äôt depend on that data too much. Things that very obviously were not helpful to my health and recovery, like having a migraine, ranked reasonably highly as contributing to my recovery in the Whoop app.  

Over my year with the Whoop, I found the app demotivating. After a two-hour workout where I spent 80 minutes at 80-90% of my max heart rate, the app told me I had a ‚Äúrestorative day.‚Äù During weeks when I was losing weight (in a calorie deficit) and exercising regularly, Whoop estimated my calorie expenditure at just 1440 calories per day, well under the 1700-1800 calories online calculators estimate someone my age, sex, height, and weight needs for at their resting metabolic rate. The calorie expenditure estimates during my workouts were laughably low; I was once credited with 33 calories for 25 minutes of rowing at a moderate pace. Two days later, the app said a 30-minute moderate rowing workout burning 202 calories‚Äîstill low but a wildly different number. 

I wanted better ways to track my workouts while using Whoop. My first problem is that some number of my highest strain workouts are in the backcountry. Without a cell signal, Whoop routinely loses data, especially if you have more than one workout in a day. There is no automated way to compare data (distances, pacing, heart rate) over time or to export it to an app that can make those comparisons. 

Charging didn‚Äôt work well on my device (v 4.0). Overnight charging never restored the battery to better than 90 percent. Most recently, I awoke to find my battery had gone from 8 percent to just 40-something percent while I slept. The battery pack is also a bit uncomfortable to wear due to its bulk and weight. Sometimes a full charge last five days, and other times it last two days. 

I used the vibrating alarm a few times and then never again. In my experience, no amount of smacking it‚Äîhard enough to awaken my bed partner‚Äîwould shut it off. Perhaps because my heart rate remains low after awakening, the device didn‚Äôt register that I was awake?

The device and app also feel like they are in constant beta mode, and I expected more for the price. I think I‚Äôm going to go for a tried-and-tested Apple Watch as my next wearable.
